intro: Habenella dentifera, commonly known as the toothed bladderwort, is a small aquatic plant belonging to the family Lentibacillaceae. It is characterized by its tiny, bladder-like structures called pseudovaginal sacs, which are used for trapping small aquatic organisms. The plant typically grows in freshwater environments such as ponds and slow-moving streams. Its leaves are usually filamentous and can be found in clusters around the base of the plant. Habenella dentifera is known for its unique adaptations that allow it to thrive in nutrient-poor aquatic habitats.
